Total accessible early-stage grant capital routinely surpasses $1,000,000 USD (or equivalent local currency) when combining national innovation funds, regional incentives, and prominent private/non-dilutive grantmakers. This depth of support lets founders secure multi-year runway without relying on equity financing.

Typically in the $700,000–1,000,000 USD range, blending national programs, regional innovation grants, and well-funded private competitions. Funding is abundant but competitive proposals, reporting discipline, and milestone alignment remain essential.

Approximately $350,000–$700,000 USD; solid public and private options exist, including SBIR-like avenues, with ecosystem support for game dev. Some programs may require alignment to research milestones or specific tech focus.
About $150,000–$350,000 USD; viable for MVP-to-demo-stage grants via SBIR Phase I-like pathways or state/private programs. Expect competition and some administrative effort.
Around $75,000–$150,000 USD; more modest but real access through targeted grants and accelerators. It’s good when paired with private funding or ongoing grant cycles.
Approximately $25,000–$75,000 USD; microgrants and contest prizes exist but may not sustain runway. Strong when combined with matching funds or serial grant applications.
About $5,000–$25,000 USD; small-grant opportunities useful for prototyping or MVP validation. They are rarely a primary funding source.
Less than $5,000 USD; very limited programs exist with narrow scope. These require targeted efforts and may not align with full startup needs.
Under $1,000 USD; practically few meaningful early-stage grants available. Expect competition and limited impact.
No meaningful early-stage grant capital accessible in the current ecosystem. Plan to rely on other funding avenues (bootstrapping, customer pre-sales) while building the pipeline.
